newsitem.title: USA: South Carolina advances tax supermajority bill.
newsitem.headline: South Carolina advances tax supermajority bill.

text.p: A South Carolina House committee has approved a constitutional amendment that would require two-thirds approval by legislators for tax increases, the State reported.

The proposal approved Wednesday by the House Judiciary Committee would call for public referendums on tax increases that were approved by more than half of legislators, but fell short of the two-thirds requirement.

The committee weakened the proposal by making the two-thirds rule apply only to taxes and not to fees. That angered committee member Rep. Jake Knotts, R-Lexington, who said, "A fee is just a tax increase masquerading as a fee."

Critics said the portion calling for public votes was also weak. If a tax bill obtained a majority, but not two-thirds approval, in the legislature, the governor could prevent a referendum by vetoing the bill. It would then take two-thirds vote in the legislature to override the veto,
The bill now goes to the full House.
